entry.title: Amy Sawyer (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Amy Sawyer (pictured) was the only woman to contribute to the more than a thousand illustrations created for H. Rider Haggard's works during his lifetime?

entry.title: elected in 1978 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that President Ieremia Tabai of Kiribati was elected in 1978, 1982, 1983 and 1987, although his eligibility for the fourth term was subject to a legal challenge?

entry.title: Zou Heng (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Chinese archaeologist Zou Heng was forced to work as a poultry farmer during the Cultural Revolution?

entry.title: the American Pigeon Museum & Library (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the American Pigeon Museum & Library keeps a flock of hundreds of pigeons for public viewing?

entry.title: Jarrett Robertson (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Major General Jarrett Robertson earned the nickname "Desert Fox" by having similar skills in battle to German field marshal Erwin Rommel, who held the same nickname?

entry.title: 2009 Dusky Sound earthquake (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that despite being New Zealand's biggest earthquake in 78 years, the 2009 Dusky Sound earthquake caused only minor damage?

entry.title: Reggie Brown (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that college football player Reggie Brown tore three knee ligaments but still made it to the NFL?

entry.title: No Obligation (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Linda Lindas wrote No Obligation, their second album, during breaks from school and touring?

entry.title: Historia Divae Monacellae (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Historia Divae Monacellae, a medieval hagiography, tells of wild hares performing miracles?
